results.title: Power from the Valley
results.creator_credit: SEC Public Relations Dept and Jim Hayes
results.brief_description: More than 80% of Victoria’s electricity comes from brown coal. The film shows coal mining, briquette making, pollution control and the beautification and restoration of nature in the Latrobe Valley as well as shots of the Hazelwood, Morwell, and Yallourn power stations and plants and the plans for Loy Yang.

results.title: Power from the snow
results.creator_credit: John Martin-Jones, Australian National Film Board and Gunnar Isakson
results.brief_description: A survey of the Snowy Mountains Hydroelectric Scheme. Shows the commencement of work in 1949, surveying the area and design of the first part of the project. Culminates in the official opening by the Prime Minister of the new Munyang Power Station, a few miles downstream from Guthega Dam which supplies it with water. Work continues on this great project, estimated to take twenty-five years to complete. Over an area of 3,000 square miles, men and machines reshape the land to supply Australia with light, and power.

results.title: Power from Kiewa waters
results.brief_description: The story of the harnessing of the waters from the Bogong High Plains for use in generating hydro-electric power in Victoria.

results.title: Power from Kiewa
results.brief_description: The multiple uses of water are investigated in the Kiewa Hydro-Electric Scheme. The efficient management of water in the catchment area, production of electricity in hydro-electric power stations and regulations of water in the Kiewa Valley are highlighted.

results.title: Power for Uganda
results.creator_credit: Gateway Film Productions and W. Hugh Baddeley
results.brief_description: Records the planning, construction, and opening of the Owen Falls hydro-electric station near the source of the Nile River. A model is used to explain the purpose of the various dams. Stresses the importance of the dam to Uganda, for as well as harnessing power for industry it will provide an adequate year-round supply of water.

results.title: Power for the highlands
results.creator_credit: A Paul Rotha Production and Jack Chambers
results.brief_description: The mountains and glens of Scotland’s highlands look beautiful to the visitor. Yet there are few people living there. Bracken has wasted the hill-sides, where the land which should be supporting sheep and cattle lies unchecked towards sea-level, taking the topsoil with it, and turning the valleys into bogs. The North of Scotland Hydro-Electricity Board was set up to convert this ruinous water into power, and to promote and develop the highlands. This film was shot in Gen Aric, Strathfarrar, Duckie and Galloway.

results.title: Power changes Mexico
results.creator_credit: International Bank for Reconstruction and Development
results.brief_description: Shows the importance of electric power for Mexico’s people, explaining how industrialization offers new careers, eases the burden for women in the villages and generally promises a higher standard of living. Shows contrast of riches and poverty in Mexico, illustrating how hydro-electric schemes raise the general welfare of the community as a whole.

results.title: Power and the political man
results.creator_credit: Country Education Project and David Zweck
results.brief_description: A panel consisting of Peter Couchman, Tony Staley, David McKenzie, Bruce Grant and Graham Little consider the theme: Power and the political man. Issues dicussed include the ways in which power is achieved; why some seek power, how power is exercised and the effect it has on those who achieve it and then lose it; and the sources of power. The discussion covers these issues as they relate to the texts; “The Prince” by Machiavelli, “Mahatma Gandhi and his Apostles” by Ved Mehta, “All the Kings Men” by Robert Penn Warren and “Quiet Americans” by Graham Greene.

results.title: Power and the land
results.creator_credit: United States. Film Service, United States. Dept. of Agriculture and Joris Ivens
results.brief_description: Sensitive portrayal of American ideals and lifestyles, made to explain and promote the Department of Agriculture’s program of rural electrification. Filmed on the farm of Bill and Hazel Parkinson in St. Clairsville, Ohio, capturing the hardship of a nonelectrified farm and the progress and profit brought by electricity. The film is critical of the reluctance by public utility companies to install power to rural areas. A significant documentary that elevates the status of farmers and the value of their work. Cinematography, Floyd Crosby and Arthur Ornitz. Script, Edwin Locke. Editing, Helen van Dongen. Commentary by Stephen Vincent Benet. Music, Douglas Moore.

results.title: Power and terror: Noam Chomsky in our times
results.brief_description: A series of lectures by eminent American expert on foreign policy, Noam Chomsky, are centred around the issues of September 11 - the United States’ response to the disaster, as well as the Government’s participation in terrorism. Chomsky displays his signature articulation and intelligence in these illuminating pieces, providing a complex picture of world politics. He deftly places the terrorist attacks in the context of American foreign intervention throughout the decades: for example in Vietnam, Central America and the Middle East. In stark and uncompromising terms Chomsky presents his views that challenge widely held perceptions about America’s motivations, in a refreshingly composed and astute way. Some lectures include question and answer forums with the audience.
